column1: The following is a list of the most populous incorporated places of the United States. As defined by the United States Census Bureau
column2: an "incorporated place" includes a variety of designations
column3: including city
column7: and municipality. A few exceptional census-designated places (CDPs) are also included in the Census Bureau's listing of incorporated places. Consolidated city-counties represent a distinct type of government that includes the entire population of a county
column8: or county equivalent. Some consolidated city-counties
column10: include multiple incorporated places. This list presents only that portion (or "balance") of such consolidated city-counties that are not a part of another incorporated place.

column1: This list refers only to the population of individual municipalities within their defined limits; the populations of other municipalities considered suburbs of a central city are listed separately
column2: and unincorporated areas within urban agglomerations are not included. Therefore
column3: a different ranking is evident when considering U.S. metropolitan area populations.

== Island Areas ==
The U.S. Census Bureau has a defined area called the "Island Areas" — it contains every major U.S. territory except Puerto Rico. There are no cities in the Island Areas with more than 100
column2: 000 people. Below are the most populous cities in the Island Areas as of 2010.Saipan and Charlotte Amalie are capital cities
column3: while Tafuna and Dededo are not.

column1: == Census-designated places ==
The following table lists U.S. census-designated places (CDPs) with populations of at least 100
column2: 000 according to the 2010 Census.  A CDP is a concentration of population identified by the United States Census Bureau for statistical purposes. CDPs are delineated for each decennial census as the statistical counterparts of incorporated places such as cities
column3: towns and villages. CDPs are populated areas that lack separate municipal government
column4: but which otherwise physically resemble incorporated places.  Unlike the incorporated cities in the main list
column5: the US Census Bureau does not release annual population estimates for CDPs.
